On Fri, 7 Feb 2003, Eric Armstrong wrote:

> The question is this: I have an existing app is that is in dire need of
> refactoring. Clearly, I need a test suite. The need for refactoring is
> made obvious by the fact that fixing some bugs tends to generate
> others, so an even more important reason to create the test suite is
> to make sure that I have thought through the desired behaviors and
> have verified that they will occur.

I've been there.

Unfortunately, in many cases these applications are written in a way
that make them extremely difficult to unit test. Especially if the
design is not very modular, it can be nearly impossible to get any
reasonable unit test coverage without modifying the application to make
it more modular. In such cases, if you can, it might be worth writing
an automated functional test suite first, getting as much coverage
from that as you can, so that you can use that to help verify that
your changes are not breaking the system behaviour that is currently
working. But often you just have to live with the pain of breaking
untested things as you modify the application. That's unfortunate, but
since you break the application anyway every time you touch it, if the
current situation calls for continuing modifications in the future
you're going to be breaking it anyway. You might as well be using the
need for changes to try and bring the application into a more testable
state.

The key here, I've found, is just clean up the bits you are directly
touching as you add features and fix bugs. Keep the changes to other
parts of the system as minimal as possible, and don't go changing
something just for the sake of adding testing to it. If a particular
piece of code really is broken, you'll have a bug report and thus a
reason to go changing it.
